item.title: Is an Intel N100 a better value than a Raspberry Pi?
item.description: tl;dr: it depends.

item.title: NVIDIA is full of shit
item.description: Since the disastrous launch of the RTX 50 series, NVIDIA has been unable to escape negative headlines: scalper bots are snatching GPUs away from consumers before official sales even begin, power connectors continue to melt, with no fix in sight, marketing is becoming increasingly deceptive, GPUs are missing processing units when they leave the factory, and the drivers, for which NVIDIA has always been praised, are currently falling apart. And to top it all off, NVIDIA is becoming increasingly insistent that media push a certain narrative when reporting on their hardware.

item.title: Using .NET Aspire With the Docker Publisher
item.description: A practical walkthrough of using .NET Aspire's Docker publisher to generate Docker Compose files from C# code. Learn how to set up an API with Postgres and Redis, publish to Docker Compose, and deploy to a VPS with minimal configuration.

item.title: Lightfast Testing: 50+ Coloured Pencil Brands
item.description: Discover the best and worst coloured pencils and markers for lightfastness, ensuring your artwork stays vibrant and doesn't fade too quickly.

item.title: How Many Agents Does it Take to Beat PyTorch?(surprisingly not that much)
item.description: Or: What happens when you give AI-agents a GPU and tell them to make it go brrr.

item.title: Intra: design notes on an LLM-driven text adventure
item.description: Last year I participated in a text adventure hackathon to build a text-based game using AI. I’d already been thinking about it but it was a great opportunity to put together those thoughts into something real. Since then I made many improvements, and while I’ve shelved the project for other endeavors I still want to write up what I’ve learned along the way.

item.title: Bad Prompting Is the New Bad Engineering
item.description: Built the same crossword app twice. Bad prompt took 6+ hours, good prompt took 40 minutes. Prompt engineering is actually a real skill.
item.author: (Ryan Perry)

item.title: Building a message board for Claude, learning MCP along the way
item.description:
I read an interesting post recently about creating a hackable AI assistant. There were a lot of things that appealed to me about it:

item.title: Lessons From Creating My First Text Adventure
item.description: When I write about the greatness of text adventures, I pretend they are easy to make. They are, compared to many other types of games, but it’s still a bit of a lie. They’re hard to make.

item.title: Process Vs Prejudice
item.description: I recently read an interesting article about Accountability Sinks. In it, the author argues that part of the reason for having business processes is that they diffuse accountability. Every one of us has tried to have an argument with an employee of a big company, and it always goes like this: the human being you are speaking to is only allowed to follow a set of processes and rules that pass on …

item.title: Switch project, part 3 - what Microchip doesn't (officially) tell you about the VSC8512
item.description: This is part 3 of my ongoing series about LATENTRED, my project to create an open source 1U managed Ethernet switch from scratch.

item.title: How much code does that proc macro generate?
item.description: Rust’s proc macros are powerful but tricky, and have some compile-time costs. This post is about a new tool to help quantify and reduce some of those costs.

item.title: Opening up ‘Zero-Knowledge Proof’ technology to promote privacy in age assurance
item.description: Today, we open sourced our Zero-Knowledge Proof (ZKP) libraries, fulfilling a promise and building on our partnership with Sparkasse to support EU age assurance.
